    "advantages": [
      "Proven efficacy in treating moderate to severe UC.",

pro1: Proven efficacy in treating moderate to severe UC. Higher safety profile compared to other biologics. Ranked highest for maintenance of clinical remission and endoscopic improvement. May be effective in treating articular extraintestinal manifestations.
cons1: Requires regular monitoring and follow-up to assess response and manage potential side effects. Limited long-term safety and efficacy data available. Differences in study design and lack of information on safety stratified by prior TNFa antagonist exposure may bias safety results. Limited information on safety compared to other biologics.
pro2: Proven efficacy in treating moderate to severe UC. May be effective in treating articular extraintestinal manifestations. Long-term safety and efficacy data available. Different mechanism of action compared to other biologics.
cons2: Requires regular monitoring and follow-up to assess response and manage potential side effects. Potential for serious infections and malignancies. Limited head-to-head trial data compared to other biologics. Higher risk of serious adverse events compared to other biologics.

cons2: Limited long-term safety data for ustekinumab in UC. May increase the risk of serious infections and malignancies. Requires subcutaneous injections.

pro1: Vedolizumab has shown higher safety compared to other biological drugs, with low rates of serious infections. It is administered intravenously, allowing for precise dosing and monitoring. Vedolizumab has a favorable safety profile in patients with prior exposure to TNF antagonists. It can be used as both induction and maintenance therapy for UC.
cons1: Regular monitoring of the patient's condition and response to treatment is necessary. The long-term safety of vedolizumab in the treatment of UC is still being evaluated. Vedolizumab may not be the most appropriate choice for patients with congestive cardiac failure, as its safety in this population is not well-established.
pro2: Ustekinumab has shown efficacy in inducing and maintaining remission in moderate to severe UC. It is administered subcutaneously, allowing for convenient self-administration. Ustekinumab has a different mechanism of action compared to TNF antagonists, which may be beneficial for patients who have failed or are intolerant to TNF antagonists. It can be used as both induction and maintenance therapy for UC.
cons2: Regular monitoring of the patient's condition and response to treatment is necessary. The long-term safety of ustekinumab in the treatment of UC is still being evaluated. Ustekinumab may not be the most appropriate choice for patients with congestive cardiac failure, as its safety in this population is not well-established.
